messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:40): HTML 5 should probably say how the native semantics map to MSAA/IAccessible2/ATK/UX
6d05f0c2942adc25946a4b02b37ffa00 (17:41): that'd be part of the rendering section
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:42): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9, thanks, search is fixed
6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b (17:45): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Alternatively that could go in a seperate, normative document
6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b (17:46): (dunno if that has significant advantages or not)

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:46): 6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b: yeah, but given the ARIA situation, the features of HTML5 that are supposed to have accessibility benefits should be documented to have them with processing reqs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:46): 6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b, if someone is willing to edit :p

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:48): 6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b: btw, it isn't just aria-level that doesn't have processing reqs. *none* of the states and properties come with processing reqs
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, is this of any use: http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/ARIA_UA_Best_Practices
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:49): normally uses "g site:opera.com bar"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:50): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: that's the kind of stuff that I'd like to see in W3C docs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:50): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9, that's for ARIA, not HTML5
6ae851943442cd6257977e31ae27830b (17:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Yeah, I had kind of noticed that aria is processing-requirment-deficient

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:50): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: so yes, that doc is useful, but by not having it in the ARIA spec, de facto normativeness is moved from the W3C doc to the Mozilla wiki.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (17:51): Aaron told me he wrote it about a week ago, and that it's a draft, so maybe there are plans to fold it in at some point
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:57): i'll still have to review that doc
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:58): making it a w3c doc has been discussed
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:58): I think the proposal was to make it a non-normative w3c doc which is possibly still a wiki
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:59): even if the API-specific stuff is better on a wiki, the spec still could have processing requirements without naming the concrete API identifiers
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:59): making it a rec-track document at this point is expected to slow down development of the doc
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (17:59): it can still become a rec-track document later on
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:00): I don't see the benefit of ARIA itself becoming a REC if as a REC it can't serve as a basis for interoperable implementations
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (18:00): me neither
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:00): From what I know the idea is to gather implementor feedback first until it's sort of done and then rubberstamp it.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:00): that is, I think shipping interoperable software is more interesting that marking a spec done
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:01): re above ^^
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:06): anyway, I think I'm going to take a second attempt at integrating ARIA into HTML5 on the document conformance level
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:06): since it now appears that aria-owns doesn't really arbitrarily reparent stuff
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:22): hmm. ARIA has script-managed alternatives for HTML5 contextmenu, draggable and irrelevent
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:25): finds a bug in HTML5
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:25): People misspell 'irrelevant'
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:26): Something like "inactive" would be less likely to go wrong
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:26): yeah, it should be renamed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: can irrelevent be misspelled by know knowing the spelling? or just typoing?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:27): hah. I typoed it just there
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:28): anyway, it seems about as typoable as any word of that length
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:29): contextmenu is way easier
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:29): no confusing over double r/l or single, no e/a issue at the end
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:29): confusion, even
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:29): we might as well drop the semantic fig leaf and call it 'hidden'
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:29): Hixie claims it's not equivalent
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): Why should we listen to him?
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:32): fwiw, irrelevant is a difficult word, even for an Englishman, for precisely the reasons Anne gives
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:37): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c and b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, both inactive and hidden are easier than irrelevant for me
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (18:39): latent maybe?
0da07476c4bd14079ce4032a6f280e17 (18:39): not that I think anyone'll miss it, but, http://annevankesteren.nl/2008/03/acid3-opera-98
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:41): irrelevant seems to be about revealing new parts of a page which weren't relevant when the user originally visited the page
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:42): putting such things on a different page seems like a better idea to me
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:43): in practice, having a different page is too cumbersome and authors instead just use display:none
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:44): Disabling stylesheets on gmail.com was suggested as a demonstration where critical semantics of the page are only encoded in its CSS
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:46): (and it seems it would be infeasible to split it into multiple pages, because that would destroy the performance)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:46): (hence it's good to have a way to encode the display:none semantics in HTML instead)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:46): style="display:none;"
bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9 (18:48): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what's meant by 'post-Kestrel'? is it just internal build that isn't public yet?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:48): That doesn't help the hypothetical UAs that want to render sites like Gmail without having to implement CSS
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:48): isn't sure it's actually solving a real problem
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:49): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: in the past X-Smiles and Prince have supported style='' without supporting the cascade
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (18:50): IIRC Prince for SVG and X-Smiles for XForms
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:50): bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9, it means it won't be part of the Kestrel release
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (18:52): i wonder if it would be feasable to just make style='display:none' mean irrelevant=''
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:52): irrelevant has some strange restrictions, such as not using it for tabbed views
bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9 (18:52): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: ah, so this is part of dev for 10? or would we see it between 9.5 and 10?

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:53): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: It's (arguably) not strange - the other tabs are still relevant to the current application state, they're just not visible in the current view
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:54): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, authors are not going to care about such distinctions
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (18:55): if the user is viewing the tab about e.g. product specification, the other tabs are currently irrelevant to them
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:55): bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9, we'll see
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (18:55): bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9, it's likely there'll be a public build demonstrating it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:56): 42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9: It does seem like a fairly subtle issue for authors to understand
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:57): and I don't think practical experience of HTML gives much hope of authors getting subtleness right

bbcc6850ce562ee262c496a76073cfc9 (18:57): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: ok, thanks, sorry, I realise answering those kinds of questions can lead to problems.  I'd forgotten that Kestrel was just 9.5, that's fine

42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:00): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, display:none by any means (not just style) could be given the semantics irrelevant has. some widgets change a class attribute rather than set a style attribute. hiding navigation in print preview is usually done by an external stylesheet.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:01): (print preview is just a UA using media="print" so I think that should work)
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:03): in effect, I think irrelevant should be dropped. if something is hidden, it is obviously not relevant to the user at that time
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:05): but css is (supposed to be) optional
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:05): Yet, lets not try to change fundamental assumptions about CSS
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:05): s/Yet/Yes/
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:07): if those assumptions don't match what authors do, maybe they should change
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:08): maybe
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:08): I rather not
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:09): ATs can't ignore css in order to be usable, i think
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:10): browsing the web visually without CSS is not really usable, either
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:10): unless you only browse our blogs :)
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:11): i browse a lot of the web without css
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:11): via feeds
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:11): optional technologies become de facto required over time
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (19:18): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: irrelevant is only useful for dynamic scripted applications, and you don't get those in feeds
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:19): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: true
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (19:19): moreover, i get style='' applied in feeds
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (19:32): WIP: http:/ b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9.iki.fi/aria-html5-bis/

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (19:47): the point is (perhaps) less whether UAs should or shouldn't implement CSS, but whether it should be necessary to use publisher CSS to read a page. There are major disadvantages to forcing publisher CSS on users (because it's very hard to design a skin everyone can use, and very few people trye).
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (19:47): *try

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (19:47): and in practice, once you're allowed users to set their own skin, presentation has become separated from content and it doesn't really make much sense to require UA support of CSS.
42e76c77af424a4350ab0e3e3f6f2ce9 (19:58): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee, good point
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:14): small update: http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2008/03/26/opera-and-the-acid3-test
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (20:14): there's a small rendering glitch left
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (20:15): wow, awesome
